name.description:
Name of the coordinate reference system.
To be used as a value for the `crs` query parameter

wkt.description: Well Known Text representation of the coordinate reference system

spatial.description: Horizontal (XY) extent of the dataset (in native CRS)

bbox.description: One or more bounding boxes that describe the spatial extent of the dataset

items.description:
Bounding box defined by four coordinates:
- Lower left corner, axis 1 (min. x)
- Lower left corner, axis 2 (min. y)
- Upper right corner, axis 1 (max. x)
- Upper right corner, axis 2 (max. y)

Reference system of the coordinates is defined by the `crs` property below

crs.description: Definition of the coordinate reference system of the dataset

interval.description:
Array of string items. Each item specifies either
- single coordinate, e.g. `2020-02-15T00:00Z`
- interval of coordinates:
  - Bounded interval, e.g. `2020-02-15T00:00Z/2020-02-16T00:00Z`
  - Left-unbounded interval, e.g. `null/2020-02-16T00:00Z`
  - Right-unounded interval, e.g. `2020-02-15T00:00Z/null`
  - Unbounded interval, e.g. `null/null`
- arithmetic sequence `<begin>/<end>/<step>`, e.g. `2020-02-15T00:00Z/2020-02-16T00:00Z/PT3H`
  (equivalent to `2020-02-15T00:00Z,2020-02-15T03:00Z,2020-02-15T06:00Z,...,2020-02-16T00:00Z`)

The overall extent is the union of items.

Coordinates are represented in RFC3339 date and time format.

Intervals are closed, i.e. boundary points are included.
`<begin>` and `<end>` coordinates of the arithmetic sequence are also included

trs.description: Definition of the temporal reference system of the dataset

interval.description:
Array of string items. Each item specifies either
- single coordinate, e.g. `100`
- interval of coordinates:
  - Bounded interval, e.g. `50/1000`
  - Left-unbounded interval, e.g. `null/1000`
  - Right-unounded interval, e.g. `50/null`
  - Unbounded interval, e.g. `null/null`
- arithmetic sequence `<begin>/<end>/<step>`, e.g. `0/100/5` (equivalent to `0,5,10,15,...,100`)

The overall extent is the union of items.

Reference system of the coordinates is defined by the `vrs` property below.

Intervals are closed, i.e. boundary points are included.
`<begin>` and `<end>` coordinates of the arithmetic sequence are also included

get.summary: Retrieve data from {collectionId} collection for a point

parameters.name: collectionId
parameters.description: Identifier of the collection to retrieve data from.

parameters.name: coords
parameters.description:
Locations(s) to retrive data for. Defined by a Well Known Text string:

- Single location: `coords=POINT(x y)`
- List of locations: `coords=MULTIPOINT((x1 y1),(x2 y2),(x3 y3), ...)`

See <http://portal.opengeospatial.org/files/?artifact_id=25355> and 
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Well-known_text_representation_of_geometry>

`x` and `y` are coordinates in the coordinate system defined by the `crs` parameter.
If the `crs` parameter is not specified, dataset's native CRS is assumed.

Examples:
- `coords=POINT(0 51.48)`
- `coords=MULTIPOINT((38.9 -77),(48.85 2.35),(39.92 116.38))`

parameters.name: z
parameters.description:
Vertical coordinate(s) to retrieve data for. The following expressions are possible:
- Single cordinate. For example `z=850`.
- Enumeration of coordinates `z=z1,z2,z3,...`. For example `z=1000,300,850,500`.
- Interval of coordinates. Four types of intervals are possible:
  - Bounded `z=minz/maxz`. For example `z=1000/850`.
  - Unbounded bottom `z=../maxz`. For example `z=../500`.
  - Unbounded top `z=minz/..`. For example `z=850/..`.
  - Unbounded `z=../..`.

  Intervala are closed (include limit coordinates).
  Coordinates are compared by their altitude, not numerically,
  i.e. `minz` must be below `maxz` (in case of isobaric coordinates 1000 < 850, for example).

- Arithmetic sequence `R<count>/<start>/<step>`.
  For example `z=R5/1000/-100` represents 1000,900,800,700,600 

Vertical extent (available vertical coordinates) is described by the collection's/instance's metadata.

parameters.name: datetime
parameters.description:
Time coordinate(s) to retrieve data for. The following expressions are possible:
- Single cordinate. For example `datetime=2020-02-11T08:15:30`.
- Enumeration of coordinates `datetime=t1,t2,t3,...`.
  For example `datetime=2020-02-11T00:00:00,2020-02-11T06:00:00,2020-02-11T12:00:00`.
- Interval of coordinates. Four types of intervals are possible:
  - Bounded `datetime=mint/maxt`. For example `datetime=2020-02-11T00:00:00/2020-02-11T12:00:00`.
  - Unbounded bottom `datetime=../maxt`. For example `datetime=../2020-02-11T12:00:00`.
  - Unbounded top `datetime=mint/..`. For example `datetime=2020-02-11T00:00:00/..`.
  - Unbounded `datetime=../..`.

  Intervals are closed (include limit coordinates).

- Arithmetic sequence `R<count>/<start>/<step>`.
  For example, `R25/2020-07-06T00:00:00/PT1H` represents sequence 2020-07-06T00:00:00,2020-07-06T01:00:00,...,2020-07-07T00:00:00

Coordinates are expressed in ISO8601 format.
Temporal extent (available time coordinates) is described by the collection's/instance's metadata.

parameters.name: parameter-name
parameters.description:
A comma-delimited list of parameters to retrieve data for.

Parameters are referred to by their identifiers.
Valid parameter identifiers are listed in the collection's/instance's metadata.

parameters.name: crs
parameters.description:
Identifier of the coordinate reference system (CRS) to return data in.
Also specifies the CRS of the `coords` parameter.

Valid identifiers are listed in the collection's/instance's metadata.

If not supplied, CRS will default to native coordinate system of data

parameters.name: f
parameters.description:
Identifier of the output format to return the response in.

Valid identifers are listed in the collection's/instance's metadata.

parameters.description: Identifier of the collection to retrieve data from.

- Single location: `coords=POINT(x y)`

Examples:

get.summary: Retrieve data from {collectionId} collection for a polygon

parameters.name: collectionId
parameters.description: Identifier of the collection to retrieve data from.

parameters.name: coords
parameters.description:
Polygon to retrieve data for. Defined using a Well Known Text string:

```
coords=POLYGON((x1 y1, x2 y2, x3 y3, ...))
```

See <http://portal.opengeospatial.org/files/?artifact_id=25355> and 
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Well-known_text_representation_of_geometry>

`x` and `y` are coordinates in the coordinate system defined by the `crs` parameter.
If the `crs` parameter is not specified, dataset's native CRS is assumed.

For example a polygon covering South West England in WGS84 would look like: 
```
coords=POLYGON((-6.1 50.3,-4.35 51.4,-2.6 51.6,-2.8 50.6,-5.3 49.9,-6.1,50.3))
```

get.summary: Retrieve data from {collectionId} collection for a trajectory

parameters.name: collectionId
parameters.description: Identifier of the collection to retrieve data from.

parameters.name: coords
parameters.description:
Trajectory to retrieve data for. Defined by a Well Known Text string. Several types of trajectories are possible:

- An XY trajectory at a fixed vertical level and a fixed time, for example:
  ```
  coords=LINESTRING(51.14 -2.98, 51.36 -2.87, 51.03 -3.15, 50.74 -3.48, 50.9 -3.36)
  ```
  This type of trajectory can be combined with `z` and `datetime` parmeters to select specific vertical level(s) and time frame(s).
  A separate trajectory is returned for each combination of vertical level and time.
- An XYZ trajectory (vertical level varies along trajectory), for example:
  ```
  coords=LINESTRINGZ(51.14 -2.98 0.1, 51.36 -2.87 0.2, 51.03 -3.15 0.3, 50.74 -3.48 0.4, 50.9 -3.36 0.5)
  ```
  * The third coordinate specifies vertical level. Units are the same as for the `z` parameter
  * This type of trajectory can be combined with `datetime` parmeter to select specific time frames(s)
- An XYT trajectory (time varies along trajectory), for example:
  ```
  coords=LINESTRINGM(51.14 -2.98 1560507000, 51.36 -2.87 1560507600, 51.03 -3.15 1560508200, 50.74 -3.48 1560508500, 50.9 -3.36 1560510240)
  ```
  * The third coordinate specifies time in the form of a Unix timestamp <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unix_time>
  * This type of trajectory can be combined with `z` parmeter to select specific vertical level(s)
- An XYZT trajectory (both vertical level and time vary along trajectory), for example:
  ```
  coords=LINESTRINGZM(51.14 -2.98 0.1 1560507000,51.36 -2.87 0.2 1560507600, 51.03 -3.15 0.3 1560508200, 50.74 -3.48 0.4 1560508500, 50.9 -3.36 0.5 1560510240)
  ```
  * The third coordinate specifies a vertical level. Units are the same as for the `z` parameter
  * The fourth coordinate specifies a time frame in the form of a Unix timestamp <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unix_time>

Using the `time` parameter with `coords=LINESTRINGM` or `coords=LINESTRINGZM` will generate a 400 error response.
Using the `z` parameter with `coords=LINESTRINGZ` or `coords=LINESTRINGZM` will generate a 400 error response.

  - Unbounded bottom `z=../maxz`. For example `z=../500`.
  - Unbounded top `z=minz/..`. For example `z=850/..`.
  - Unbounded `z=../..`.

  Intervala are closed (include limit coordinates).
  Coordinates are compared by their altitude, not numerically,
  i.e. `minz` must be below `maxz` (in case of isobaric coordinates 1000 < 850, for example).

- Arithmetic sequence `R<count>/<start>/<step>`.
  For example `z=R5/1000/-100` represents 1000,900,800,700,600

parameters.name: corridor-width
parameters.description:
Width of the corridor and the units of the width value.

Syntax: `corridor-width={width}/{units}`

The `{width}` value represents the whole width of the corridor where
the trajectory supplied in the `coords` parameter is the centre
point of the corridor.

For example, `corridor-width=100/m`

would be a request for a corridor 100m wide with the `coords` parameter values being the centre point of the requested corridor, 
the request would be for data values 50m either side of the trajectory coordinates defined in the `coords` parameter. 

The width units supported by the collection will be provided in the API metadata responses.

parameters.name: corridor-height
parameters.description:
Height of the corridor and the units of the height value.

Syntax: `corridor-height={height}/{units}`

The `{height}` value represents the whole height of the corridor where
the trajectory supplied in the `coords` parameter is the centre
point of the corridor.

For example, `corridor-height=100/m`

would be a request for a corridor 100m high with the `coords` parameter values being the centre point of the requested corridor, 
the request would be for data values 50m either side of the trajectory coordinates defined in the `coords` parameter. 

The height units supported by the collection will be provided in the API metadata responses.

crs.description: Definition of the coordinate reference system of the dataset

interval.description:
Array of string items. Each item specifies either
- single coordinate, e.g. `2020-02-15T00:00Z`
- interval of coordinates:
  - Bounded interval, e.g. `2020-02-15T00:00Z/2020-02-16T00:00Z`
  - Left-unbounded interval, e.g. `null/2020-02-16T00:00Z`
  - Right-unounded interval, e.g. `2020-02-15T00:00Z/null`
  - Unbounded interval, e.g. `null/null`
- arithmetic sequence `<begin>/<end>/<step>`, e.g. `2020-02-15T00:00Z/2020-02-16T00:00Z/PT3H`
  (equivalent to `2020-02-15T00:00Z,2020-02-15T03:00Z,2020-02-15T06:00Z,...,2020-02-16T00:00Z`)

The overall extent is the union of items.

Coordinates are represented in RFC3339 date and time format.

Intervals are closed, i.e. boundary points are included.
`<begin>` and `<end>` coordinates of the arithmetic sequence are also included

  - Right-unounded interval, e.g. `50/null`
  - Unbounded interval, e.g. `null/null`
- arithmetic sequence `<begin>/<end>/<step>`, e.g. `0/100/5` (equivalent to `0,5,10,15,...,100`)

The overall extent is the union of items.

Reference system of the coordinates is defined by the `vrs` property below.

`<begin>` and `<end>` coordinates of the arithmetic sequence are also included

spatial.description: Horizontal (XY) extent of the dataset (in native CRS)

bbox.description: One or more bounding boxes that describe the spatial extent of the dataset

items.description:
Bounding box defined by four coordinates:
- Lower left corner, axis 1 (min. x)
- Lower left corner, axis 2 (min. y)
- Upper right corner, axis 1 (max. x)
- Upper right corner, axis 2 (max. y)

Reference system of the coordinates is defined by the `crs` property below

crs.description: Definition of the coordinate reference system of the dataset

interval.description:
Array of string items. Each item specifies either
- single coordinate, e.g. `2020-02-15T00:00Z`
- interval of coordinates:
  - Bounded interval, e.g. `2020-02-15T00:00Z/2020-02-16T00:00Z`
  - Left-unbounded interval, e.g. `null/2020-02-16T00:00Z`
  - Right-unounded interval, e.g. `2020-02-15T00:00Z/null`
  - Unbounded interval, e.g. `null/null`
- arithmetic sequence `<begin>/<end>/<step>`, e.g. `2020-02-15T00:00Z/2020-02-16T00:00Z/PT3H`
  (equivalent to `2020-02-15T00:00Z,2020-02-15T03:00Z,2020-02-15T06:00Z,...,2020-02-16T00:00Z`)

The overall extent is the union of items.

Coordinates are represented in RFC3339 date and time format.

Intervals are closed, i.e. boundary points are included.
`<begin>` and `<end>` coordinates of the arithmetic sequence are also included

trs.description: Definition of the temporal reference system of the dataset

interval.description:
Array of string items. Each item specifies either
- single coordinate, e.g. `100`
- interval of coordinates:
  - Bounded interval, e.g. `50/1000`
  - Left-unbounded interval, e.g. `null/1000`
  - Right-unounded interval, e.g. `50/null`
  - Unbounded interval, e.g. `null/null`
- arithmetic sequence `<begin>/<end>/<step>`, e.g. `0/100/5` (equivalent to `0,5,10,15,...,100`)

The overall extent is the union of items.

Reference system of the coordinates is defined by the `vrs` property below.

Intervals are closed, i.e. boundary points are included.
`<begin>` and `<end>` coordinates of the arithmetic sequence are also included

get.summary: Retrieve data from {instanceId} instance for a point

parameters.name: collectionId
parameters.description: Identifier of the collection to retrieve data from.

parameters.name: instanceId
parameters.description: Identifier of the instance to retrieve data from.

parameters.name: coords
parameters.description:
Locations(s) to retrive data for. Defined by a Well Known Text string:

- Single location: `coords=POINT(x y)`
- List of locations: `coords=MULTIPOINT((x1 y1),(x2 y2),(x3 y3), ...)`

See <http://portal.opengeospatial.org/files/?artifact_id=25355> and 
<https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Well-known_text_representation_of_geometry>

`x` and `y` are coordinates in the coordinate system defined by the `crs` parameter.
If the `crs` parameter is not specified, dataset's native CRS is assumed.

Examples:
- `coords=POINT(0 51.48)`
- `coords=MULTIPOINT((38.9 -77),(48.85 2.35),(39.92 116.38))`

parameters.name: z
parameters.description:
Vertical coordinate(s) to retrieve data for. The following expressions are possible:
- Single cordinate. For example `z=850`.
- Enumeration of coordinates `z=z1,z2,z3,...`. For example `z=1000,300,850,500`.
- Interval of coordinates. Four types of intervals are possible:
  - Bounded `z=minz/maxz`. For example `z=1000/850`.
  - Unbounded bottom `z=../maxz`. For example `z=../500`.
  - Unbounded top `z=minz/..`. For example `z=850/..`.
  - Unbounded `z=../..`.

  Intervala are closed (include limit coordinates).
  Coordinates are compared by their altitude, not numerically,
  i.e. `minz` must be below `maxz` (in case of isobaric coordinates 1000 < 850, for example).

- Arithmetic sequence `R<count>/<start>/<step>`.
  For example `z=R5/1000/-100` represents 1000,900,800,700,600 

Vertical extent (available vertical coordinates) is described by the collection's/instance's metadata.

parameters.name: datetime
parameters.description:
Time coordinate(s) to retrieve data for. The following expressions are possible:
- Single cordinate. For example `datetime=2020-02-11T08:15:30`.
- Enumeration of coordinates `datetime=t1,t2,t3,...`.
  For example `datetime=2020-02-11T00:00:00,2020-02-11T06:00:00,2020-02-11T12:00:00`.
- Interval of coordinates. Four types of intervals are possible:
  - Bounded `datetime=mint/maxt`. For example `datetime=2020-02-11T00:00:00/2020-02-11T12:00:00`.
  - Unbounded bottom `datetime=../maxt`. For example `datetime=../2020-02-11T12:00:00`.
  - Unbounded top `datetime=mint/..`. For example `datetime=2020-02-11T00:00:00/..`.
  - Unbounded `datetime=../..`.

  Intervals are closed (include limit coordinates).

- Arithmetic sequence `R<count>/<start>/<step>`.
  For example, `R25/2020-07-06T00:00:00/PT1H` represents sequence 2020-07-06T00:00:00,2020-07-06T01:00:00,...,2020-07-07T00:00:00

Coordinates are expressed in ISO8601 format.
Temporal extent (available time coordinates) is described by the collection's/instance's metadata.

parameters.name: parameter-name
parameters.description:
A comma-delimited list of parameters to retrieve data for.

Parameters are referred to by their identifiers.
Valid parameter identifiers are listed in the collection's/instance's metadata.

parameters.name: crs
parameters.description:
Identifier of the coordinate reference system (CRS) to return data in.
Also specifies the CRS of the `coords` parameter.

Valid identifiers are listed in the collection's/instance's metadata.

If not supplied, CRS will default to native coordinate system of data

parameters.description:
Identifier of the output format to return the response in.

Valid identifers are listed in the collection's/instance's metadata.

parameters.description:

```
coords=POLYGON((x1 y1, x2 y2, x3 y3, ...))
```

```

```

parameters.name: collectionId
parameters.description: Identifier of the collection to retrieve data from.

parameters.name: instanceId
parameters.description: Identifier of the instance to retrieve data from.

parameters.name: coords
parameters.description:
Trajectory to retrieve data for. Defined by a Well Known Text string. Several types of trajectories are possible:

- An XY trajectory at a fixed vertical level and a fixed time, for example:
  ```
  coords=LINESTRING(51.14 -2.98, 51.36 -2.87, 51.03 -3.15, 50.74 -3.48, 50.9 -3.36)
  ```
  This type of trajectory can be combined with `z` and `datetime` parmeters to select specific vertical level(s) and time frame(s).
  A separate trajectory is returned for each combination of vertical level and time.
- An XYZ trajectory (vertical level varies along trajectory), for example:
  ```
  coords=LINESTRINGZ(51.14 -2.98 0.1, 51.36 -2.87 0.2, 51.03 -3.15 0.3, 50.74 -3.48 0.4, 50.9 -3.36 0.5)
  ```
  * The third coordinate specifies vertical level. Units are the same as for the `z` parameter
  * This type of trajectory can be combined with `datetime` parmeter to select specific time frames(s)
- An XYT trajectory (time varies along trajectory), for example:
  ```
  coords=LINESTRINGM(51.14 -2.98 1560507000, 51.36 -2.87 1560507600, 51.03 -3.15 1560508200, 50.74 -3.48 1560508500, 50.9 -3.36 1560510240)
  ```
  * The third coordinate specifies time in the form of a Unix timestamp <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unix_time>
  * This type of trajectory can be combined with `z` parmeter to select specific vertical level(s)
- An XYZT trajectory (both vertical level and time vary along trajectory), for example:
  ```
  coords=LINESTRINGZM(51.14 -2.98 0.1 1560507000,51.36 -2.87 0.2 1560507600, 51.03 -3.15 0.3 1560508200, 50.74 -3.48 0.4 1560508500, 50.9 -3.36 0.5 1560510240)
  ```
  * The third coordinate specifies a vertical level. Units are the same as for the `z` parameter
  * The fourth coordinate specifies a time frame in the form of a Unix timestamp <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unix_time>

Using the `time` parameter with `coords=LINESTRINGM` or `coords=LINESTRINGZM` will generate a 400 error response.
Using the `z` parameter with `coords=LINESTRINGZ` or `coords=LINESTRINGZM` will generate a 400 error response.

parameters.name: z
parameters.description:
Vertical coordinate(s) to retrieve data for. The following expressions are possible:
- Single cordinate. For example `z=850`.
- Enumeration of coordinates `z=z1,z2,z3,...`. For example `z=1000,300,850,500`.
- Interval of coordinates. Four types of intervals are possible:
  - Bounded `z=minz/maxz`. For example `z=1000/850`.
  - Unbounded bottom `z=../maxz`. For example `z=../500`.
  - Unbounded top `z=minz/..`. For example `z=850/..`.
  - Unbounded `z=../..`.

  Intervala are closed (include limit coordinates).
  Coordinates are compared by their altitude, not numerically,
  i.e. `minz` must be below `maxz` (in case of isobaric coordinates 1000 < 850, for example).

- Arithmetic sequence `R<count>/<start>/<step>`.
  For example `z=R5/1000/-100` represents 1000,900,800,700,600 

Vertical extent (available vertical coordinates) is described by the collection's/instance's metadata.

parameters.name: datetime
parameters.description:
Time coordinate(s) to retrieve data for. The following expressions are possible:
- Single cordinate. For example `datetime=2020-02-11T08:15:30`.
- Enumeration of coordinates `datetime=t1,t2,t3,...`.
  For example `datetime=2020-02-11T00:00:00,2020-02-11T06:00:00,2020-02-11T12:00:00`.
- Interval of coordinates. Four types of intervals are possible:
  - Bounded `datetime=mint/maxt`. For example `datetime=2020-02-11T00:00:00/2020-02-11T12:00:00`.
  - Unbounded bottom `datetime=../maxt`. For example `datetime=../2020-02-11T12:00:00`.
  - Unbounded top `datetime=mint/..`. For example `datetime=2020-02-11T00:00:00/..`.
  - Unbounded `datetime=../..`.

  Intervals are closed (include limit coordinates).

- Arithmetic sequence `R<count>/<start>/<step>`.
  For example, `R25/2020-07-06T00:00:00/PT1H` represents sequence 2020-07-06T00:00:00,2020-07-06T01:00:00,...,2020-07-07T00:00:00

Coordinates are expressed in ISO8601 format.
Temporal extent (available time coordinates) is described by the collection's/instance's metadata.

parameters.name: parameter-name
parameters.description:
A comma-delimited list of parameters to retrieve data for.

Parameters are referred to by their identifiers.
Valid parameter identifiers are listed in the collection's/instance's metadata.

parameters.name: corridor-width
parameters.description:
Width of the corridor and the units of the width value.

Syntax: `corridor-width={width}/{units}`

The `{width}` value represents the whole width of the corridor where
the trajectory supplied in the `coords` parameter is the centre
point of the corridor.

For example, `corridor-width=100/m`

would be a request for a corridor 100m wide with the `coords` parameter values being the centre point of the requested corridor, 
the request would be for data values 50m either side of the trajectory coordinates defined in the `coords` parameter. 

The width units supported by the collection will be provided in the API metadata responses.

parameters.name: corridor-height
parameters.description:
Height of the corridor and the units of the height value.

Syntax: `corridor-height={height}/{units}`

The `{height}` value represents the whole height of the corridor where
the trajectory supplied in the `coords` parameter is the centre
point of the corridor.

For example, `corridor-height=100/m`

would be a request for a corridor 100m high with the `coords` parameter values being the centre point of the requested corridor, 
the request would be for data values 50m either side of the trajectory coordinates defined in the `coords` parameter. 

The height units supported by the collection will be provided in the API metadata responses.
